root.pub-comments: This tree is from personal communication between Dr. Claire Bowern and Danielle St. Jean, received on November 14, 2009 at the ELIIP Workshop in Salt Lake City, UT. It should be noted that there are fringe languages which may fall somewhere within this subgrouping, but to date there is not enough evidence to place them definitively in the Proto-Karnic subgroup. These languages are Pirriya, Yanda, Guwa (Goa), and Kungkari.

child.pub-comments: Claire Bowern noted that the Eastern Karnic subgroup was perhaps best interpretted as a dialect continuum.
Ethnologue lists "Wangkumara" as a dialect of Ngura (ISO 639-3: nbx) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nbx).
Ethnologue lists "Punthamara" as a dialect of Ngura (ISO 639-3: nbx) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nbx).
AUSTLANG quotes Claire Bowern from 2001, explaining how she categorizes it as a dialect close to Wangkumara (http://austlang.aiatsis.gov.au/).

Ethnologue lists "Garlali" as a dialect of Ngura (ISO 639-3: nbx) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nbx). AUSTLANG comments on the uncertainties involved with Garlali, over whether it is grouped with Wangkumara and what its name is (http://austlang.aiatsis.gov.au/main.php).
According to Ethnologue, "Yarluyandji" is an alternate name for Ngamini (ISO 639-3 nmv) (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=nmv).
The term Yandruwandha, which is the name of the most well attested variety in this subgroup, is also used as a cover term for the subgroup itself.

AUSTLANG quotes Claire Bowern from 2001 in regards to the potential placement of Karuwali in the Karnic Subgrouping (http://austlang.aiatsis.gov.au/). In the Ethnologue 15 entry for Dieri (ISO 639-3 dif), "Garuwali" is listed as potentially being related, but there is no seperate entry on Garuwali (http://www.ethnologue.com/15/show_language.asp?code=dif).
AUSTLANG places the language "Maiawali" within their Northwestern Karnic subgroup (http://austlang.aiatsis.gov.au/)
